intro: Aster nigrocinctus, commonly known as the black-belt aster, is a flowering plant native to the central and eastern United States. It is characterized by its showy, violet-blue flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. The plant has hairy stems and leaves with a rough texture, and its flowers are typically arranged in clusters at the tips of the stems. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands, prairies, and along stream banks. The species is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance as a food source for pollinators.
